children.value: Welcome to GTSAM! Please follow this guide to use GTSAM on your platform.
First, make sure to use a compatible operating system and compiler:
Then install the following libraries on your system:
These additional libraries are used automatically—if findable by CMake.
If oneTBB is installed and detectable by CMake, GTSAM will use it automatically. Ensure that CMake prints
To disable the use of TBB, disable the CMake flag
, TBB may be installed from the Ubuntu repositories, and for other platforms it may be downloaded from
MKL may not provide a speedup in all cases.
Make sure to benchmark your problem with and without MKL.
GTSAM may be configured to use MKL by toggling
. However, best performance is usually achieved with MKL
. We therefore advise you to benchmark your problem before using MKL.

Intel has a guide
for installing MKL on Linux through APT repositories

(and afterwards, open a new terminal before compiling GTSAM):

To use MKL in GTSAM pass the flag
fix seems to be related to a well known problem with MKL which leads to lots of undefined symbol errors, for example:
may lead to errors such as:
Intel MKL FATAL ERROR: Cannot load libmkl_avx2.so or libmkl_def.so.

sudo apt-get install libboost-all-dev   # Boost
sudo apt-get install cmake              # Cmake
Clone or download the latest release from the
Then execute the commands below in the root directory for an out-of-source build.

#!bash
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ make check    # optional, runs unit tests
$ make install
This will build the library and unit tests (to the default system install path), run all of the unit tests, and then install the library itself.
GTSAM can be installed on Ubuntu via

as well.
As of November 2020, packages for Xenial (u16.04), Bionic (u18.04), and Focal (u20.04) are published.
Follow the code below to add PPA for your preferred branch:

# Add PPA
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:borglab/gtsam-release-4.0
sudo apt update  # not necessary since Bionic
# Install:
sudo apt install libgtsam-dev libgtsam-unstable-dev

# Add PPA
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:borglab/gtsam-develop
sudo apt update  # not necessary since Bionic
# Install:
sudo apt install libgtsam-dev libgtsam-unstable-dev
Installing GTSAM on Arch Linux has not been tested by GTSAM developers.

GTSAM is available in the Arch User Repository

It is also recommended to use the

repository. They are hosting many packages related to education and research,
including robotics such as ROS. Adding a repository allows for you to install
binaries of packages, instead of compiling them from source.
This will greatly speed up your installation time. Visit

GTSAM has a number of options that can be configured, which is best done with
one of the following:
We support several build configurations for GTSAM (case insensitive)
: All error checking options on, no optimization. Use for development of new features and fixing issues.
: Optimizations turned on, no debug symbols.
: Adds ENABLE_TIMING flag to provide statistics on operation
: Standard configuration for use during profiling

: Same as Release, but with the - g flag
for debug symbols
The install folder. The default is typically

.
To configure to install to your home directory, you could execute:
The Matlab toolbox will be installed in a subdirectory of this folder, called
This is a build option to allow for tests in subfolders to be linked against convenience libraries rather than the full

.
Set with the command line as follows:
(Default): This builds convenience libraries and links tests against them.

This option is suggested for gtsam developers, as it is possible to build and run tests without first building the rest of the library, and speeds up compilation for a single test. The downside of this option is that it will build the entire library again to build the full libgtsam library, so build / install will be slower.
before any of the tests, and then link all of the tests at once.

This option is best
for users of GTSAM, as it avoids rebuilding the entirety of gtsam an extra time.

library.

will be built and installed with the same options as libgtsam. In addition, if tests are enabled, the unit tests will be built as well. The Matlab toolbox will also be generated

can be found by executing the command
, so we highly recommend you work in
while developing (which is not enabled by default).
Likewise, it is imperative that you switch back to release mode when running finished code and for timing.
GTSAM will run up to 10x faster in Release mode!
, which enables debug checks and safe containers in the standard C++ library and makes problems much easier to find.
The native Snow Leopard g++ compiler / library contains a bug that makes it impossible to use
. MacPorts g++ compilers do work with it though.
is used to compile gtsam, anything that links against gtsam will need to be compiled with
as well, due to the use of header - only Eigen.
Here are some tips to get the best possible performance out of GTSAM.
On modern processors with multiple cores, this can easily speed up optimization 30-50%.

Please note that this may not be true for very small problems where the overhead of dispatching work to multiple threads outweighs the benefit. We recommend that you benchmark your problem with / without TBB.
. A performance gain of 25 - 30% can be expected on modern processors.
Note that this affects the portability of your executable. It may not run when copied to another system with older / different processor architecture. Also note that all dependent projects
be compiled with the same flag, or segfaults and other undefined behavior may result.
Please note that our benchmarks have shown that this helps only in very limited cases, and actually hurts performance in the usual case. We therefore recommend that you do
enable MKL, unless you have benchmarked it on your problem and have verified that it improves performance.
